But I think that one common place where Backbone tends to run into a little bit of problems is that its views system is pretty un-opinionated. When youâ€™re really, really un-opinionated about something, itâ€™s hard, if you just want to just get up and running and build something quickly. So we see a lot of people basically using React to implement their Backbone view. I think thatâ€™s the easiest way for people to get started. Backbone just gives you a DOM element and then all you have to do is pass that DOM element into React and React will render it and manage it for you. For example, if youâ€™re decoding lots of images, itâ€™s really hard to do that. But the point is that the framework itself can run within a single requestAnimationFrame. There are also issues with garbage collection and stuff like that, but weâ€™re basically trying to get it, the framework, as quickly as possible. That involves doing a couple of things. For example, the core is written to minimize the amount of garbage that we generate. So whenever we dispatch an event, for example, weâ€™re pooling that event object. So every new event that comes in, every time you move your mouse across the page or something, weâ€™re not generating new garbage. Or at least, weâ€™re trying not to generate any garbage. We also do some really cool things with how we batch updates and how we batch reads and writes in the DOM. React is all about building components. And if you look at Facebook, for example, on every news feed story, thereâ€™s a little box where you can enter a comment and view comments and likes. If you drew a square around that, that would be a React component. Every single component on the page has a life cycle. Weâ€™ve basically built it such that at certain parts of the life cycle, every component on the page reads from the DOM and at another part of the life cycle, every component queues up the writes that itâ€™s going to do to the DOM so that can actually keep them all batched. The DOM historically has been very, very slow and a source for not being able to get that 60 frames per second. So if you can batch those up together, youâ€™re much more likely to be able to get there. MERRICK:Â  Awesome. Iâ€™m wondering, one thing thatâ€™s interesting to me is that React came out and you guys, I wouldnâ€™t say shun, but you guys didnâ€™t go with the two-way data binding. I think you articulate that was for the performance that you wanted to get. Either that or the maintainability of how it scales. Could you talk a little bit about that decision? PETE:Â  I think that Jordanâ€™s going to probably want to take that. JORDAN:Â  I think thereâ€™s value in having two-way data binding but a lot of times, if you use two-way data binding, youâ€™ll notice that a lot of the times it could have been expressed with unidirectional data binding. If we could just make that unidirectional data binding so easy because itâ€™s a common case, at the expense of possibly deferring or just not yet solving the two-way data binding problem, it can get you to a place where you can develop applications very quickly. And you still have options for two-way data binding, but then the framework isnâ€™t investing as heavily in those. So we do see value in that and I think that thereâ€™s room to experiment there. Weâ€™d love to see the community contribute and come up with ideas there. I would say that there are some downfalls when you just automatically reach to that two-way data binding paradigm. Itâ€™s inherently mutated. So unidirectional data binding can be functionally expressed, because functions have an input and they have an output. So thatâ€™s very much a one-way data binding. If you can express the majority of your application in terms of one-way data binding, you can write a very functional application that minimizes the amount of mutations. And the amount of mutations, when you increase the amount of mutations, your application complexity increases as well. So weâ€™re like forcing function at this point to help you minimize the amount of application complexity that you actually build. MERRICK:Â  Got it. JAMISON:Â  You said that in lots of places, you can replace two-way data binding with one-way data binding. Can you elaborate on that idea? It seems like theyâ€™re [solving the] [inaudible] JORDAN:Â  Oh yeah, sorry. I guess that was misleading. There are times when people use two-way data binding and what Iâ€™ve seen with more traditional two-way data binding MVC frameworks is somebody will jump to two-way data binding when they could have easily just used one-way data binding. They werenâ€™t using the opposite direction of the binding. JAMISON:Â  Oh, okay. JORDAN:Â  They just naturally jumped to that. Now there are other cases where people use two-way data binding and you could still implement that in terms of one-way data binding with an explicitly passed callback handler that handles the attempt to change that value. So itâ€™s just basically instead of having one value thatâ€™s like a model that can react to changes that you pass down, you just simply pass two values. One of them is a one-way data binding reactive value and the other is a change handler. So thereâ€™s a way to do it right now. MERRICK:Â  Thatâ€™s what I wanted to ask, is Iâ€™ve seen some crafty things, particularly in the EmberJS framework where theyâ€™re queuing up these, they have this notion of a run loop and theyâ€™re queuing up all these state changes to flush them all at once. Is that similar to how you guys have implemented it to get the performance? PETE:Â  Yeah. Iâ€™m trying to think of the best way to explain this. Letâ€™s see. Okay, so when the data changes in React, we basically, to support scalable application development, Reactâ€™s guiding principle is mutation is evil and we should try to avoid it as much as possible. The idea is that if youâ€™re program is in state 0 and then you transition to state 1 and then state 1 is dependent on state 0 and then you transition to state 2 which is dependent on state 0, itâ€™s really, really hard to think about and really hold the whole possible states your program can be in in your head. Thatâ€™s how you end up in jQuery spaghetti where youâ€™ve updated the DOM and then you have to check all these other cases that you may have changed a node and insert it into the right place, that sort of thing. MERRICK:Â  Sure. PETE:Â  So React was designed all around that. Conceptually, how you build a React app is that every time your data changes, itâ€™s like hitting the refresh button in a server-rendered app. What we do is we conceptually throw out all of the markup and event handlers that youâ€™ve registered and we reset the whole page and then we redraw the entire page. If youâ€™re writing a server-rendered app, handling updates is really easy because you hit the refresh button and youâ€™re pretty much guaranteed to get what you expect. MERRICK:Â  Thatâ€™s true. You donâ€™t get into these odd states. PETE:Â  Exactly, exactly. In order to implement that, we communicate it as a fake DOM. What weâ€™ll do is rather than throw out the actual browser html and event handlers, we have an internal representation of what the page looks like and then we generate a brand new representation of what we want the page to look like. Then we perform this really, really fast diffing algorithm between those two page representations, DOM representations. Then React will compute the minimum set of DOM mutations it needs to make to bring the page up to date. Then to finally get to answer your question, that set of DOM mutations then goes into a queue and we can plug in arbitrary flushing strategies for that. For example, when we originally launched React in open source, every setstate would immediately trigger a flush to the DOM. That wasnâ€™t part of the contract of setstate, but that was just our strategy and it worked pretty well. Then this totally awesome open source contributor Ben [Alfred] at Khan Academy built a new batching strategy which would basically queue up every single DOM update and state change that happened within an event tick and would execute them in bulk at the end of the event tick. MERRICK:Â  Awesome. PETE:Â  That was a pretty huge performance win on our ads create flow, for example. You can imagine, since weâ€™ve made all of this pluggable, we have some other cool ideas that might be interesting. For example, we just always flush at the end of a requestAnimationFrame. So if you get multiple AJAX requests coming back in a single animation frame, which is a pretty common thing to happen, itâ€™s just as fast as if it was a single one. MERRICK:Â  Yeah, thatâ€™s actually a really interesting idea. Almost like youâ€™re just going to mutate the state and paint it, kind of how you would implement a canvas app, almost. PETE:Â  Yeah. MERRICK:Â  Way more traditional UI. You get rid of a lot of the issues of writing against the DOM. PETE:Â  Exactly, exactly. I donâ€™t know if Jordanâ€™s going to agree with this, but thereâ€™s this guy online. I think his name is Fabian something and he deconstructs the Doom 3 engine source code and talks about how the game logic interacts with the renderer and interacts with the graphics card. And it looks very similar to how we structured React in that we have your application logic which is doing whatever you want, manipulating this fake DOM, and then we pass it to this rendering system that does that DOM diff and queues up those DOM operations. Then rather than OpenGL calls to a graphics card, weâ€™re just sending DOM mutations to the DOM. So it was a nice validation of the structure of React. MERRICK:Â  Yeah, see thatâ€™s really interesting. Can you explain that a little bit more? JORDAN:Â  Yeah. Itâ€™s not just about the CPU efficiency but itâ€™s also about memory efficiency. The key part here is that weâ€™re not doing this with DOM constructs. When you manipulate a DOM node, youâ€™re likely breaking outside of the BM into some native code. We believe that that context switching is actually very expensive. So weâ€™re doing this in pure JS representations, which is already a win. But one of the interesting things is that by default, this algorithm is just heavily optimized because weâ€™ve invested a lot in it and itâ€™s very critical to our site. But there are also other hooks inside of the components that allow you to [poke]/guide that process along when it comes time to optimize. So by default, you can just assume everything re-renders and for most cases, youâ€™ll never have to optimize anything. For your standard webpage, for your standard app that youâ€™re building, youâ€™ll never even have to think about it. But we give you a way to hook into the component. At the component level we give you a way to hook in and help tell React when it needs to update a certain part of the page and when it doesnâ€™t. But the really cool thing is that that optimization code is totally optional and it can be added later and it doesnâ€™t become a core part of your development paradigm. So youâ€™re not prematurely optimizing your app when you donâ€™t even know what the general structureâ€™s going to look like. Does that answer your question? JOE:Â  Yeah, absolutely. Thatâ€™s great. Thatâ€™s great. It seems like a really innovative idea to do it that way as well. I really like that idea of just determining whatâ€™s different and whatâ€™s not and figuring out and repainting it. PETE:Â  We have our own DOM manipulation library. CHUCK:Â  Thatâ€™s more or less what it sounded like. JORDAN:Â  Itâ€™s just highly optimized for the case of these large flushes. So it is abstracted. JORDAN:Â  Right. The event system though, is interesting in itself. Itâ€™s completely synthetic and itâ€™s actually pretty standalone. You could imagine using just the event system in another framework. What it is, is it completely re-implements bubbling, capturing and stopping the propagation, in a completely virtual way that doesnâ€™t rely on any DOM nodes at all. So whatâ€™s cool about that is it has an injectable plugin system where you can write your own events. For example, we have an event called onEnter, onLeave, which is like Microsoftâ€™s enter/leave events, but it works on all browsers. And you can just gracefully inject these plugins that sit there and listen to this raw stream of low-level keyboard and mouse events and infers higher-level ones. So you can write your own, either double tap or long press or anything like that and then share it with other people so they can easily use it. MERRICK:Â  Thatâ€™s really cool. MERRICK:Â  Yeah, which is just awesome. PETE:Â  So another cool thing that is implied by this is I have a branch, Iâ€™m not sure itâ€™s really worth doing at this point, but it only took maybe a day or two to get your entire React app running in a web worker which has pretty cool implications because weâ€™re pretty paranoid about performance. And if you only do the DOM manipulations in the main thread, then it makes scrolling a lot smoother and that sort of thing. So the reason weâ€™re able to do that so easily is for a couple of reasons. First of all, React barely knows that thereâ€™s a browser. Only the event plugins know about the browser and the fundamental DOM manipulation library knows about the browser. Everything else is in this synthetic fake browser world. So thatâ€™s pretty sweet. The second thing that lets us do that is since we have not committed to a standard way to do two-way data binding, the framework itself is never reading directly from the DOM. The users themselves have to read from the DOM. A lot of the pain of keeping the DOM and the virtual world synchronized is a lot easier without using two-way binding. MERRICK:Â  Yeah. You just write your components as if youâ€™re rendering them on the client and they just work on the server. CHUCK:Â  That is amazing. PETE:Â  And have you guys heard of Airbnbâ€™s rendr framework? MERRICK:Â  Yeah. PETE:Â  So there were like, I was working on the server rendering feature internally and then they launched that. I was like, â€œMan, they stole our fire,â€ because they have a really awesome, â€œOh, it runs both on the client and the server. You donâ€™t have to think about it.â€ So I ended up meeting up with those guys and Airbnb and within our 30-minute meeting, we were able to get React rendering within rendr. And rendr, if you guys arenâ€™t familiar with it, is just a way to run a Backbone app in Node.js or in the browser. So there are a lot of cool advantages for those listening that donâ€™t see whatâ€™s so exciting about server rendering. We can serve up the server-rendered page to Google Bot, for example and get your ranking up because Google Bot penalizes client-rendered pages because of performance. You can also get that really, really fast first page load experience. So imagine you write your JavaScript app just like you normally would or your React app just like you normally would. Then you just flip the switch to turn on server rendering and suddenly you donâ€™t have to wait for the JavaScript to download for your user to see the initial page. You can also manage tradeoffs on mobile devices. So for example, some mobile devices might not want to render certain components in JavaScript. You might want to render them in the server and just parse the html. We can do all of that. And itâ€™s actually a pretty elegant situation where you simply tell React, â€œHereâ€™s my component and I want you to render it into this DOM node.â€ And the first thing that React is going to do is itâ€™s going to look at that DOM node and be like, â€œHey, does it look like React generated markup in this DOM node?â€ and if itâ€™s not there, itâ€™ll generate the markup for you. If it is there, itâ€™ll skip the markup generation step, just register the event listeners, and youâ€™re good to go. And we have a way of basically hashing the markup to ensure that itâ€™s correct and that kind of thing, thatâ€™s really fast. MERRICK:Â  Thatâ€™s awesome. PETE:Â  Yeah. JAMISON:Â  Thatâ€™s really impressive. MERRICK:Â  Yeah, thatâ€™s super cool. I think one other question. You guys have this optional JSX. Traditionally in the web community, and this is probably more FUD than anything else, but thereâ€™s this huge aversion to XML. JAMISON:Â  Yeah, that was a bold move to put the letter X in there. MERRICK:Â  Yeah, so my question is do you find that most people are writing with the JSX syntax or without it? And why do you have that declarative style? Is it composable, et cetera? JORDAN:Â  I think I would say, Pete you can correct me if Iâ€™m wrong, but Iâ€™d say over 60% of people give it a shot and they stick with it. Then some people just choose not to and thatâ€™s totally cool. Is that about right, Pete? PETE:Â  Itâ€™s probably more than that. I think the people that tend to not use it are using CoffeeScript or something. JORDAN:Â  Okay, yeah. So a lot of languages had this embedded XML syntax. Scala has it, ActionScript 3. And I think thereâ€™s some part of that thatâ€™s actually good and some part of that thatâ€™s actually bad. One of the things that I donâ€™t appreciate in languages that embed XML is that they typically have this whole other semantics to it. Itâ€™s a runtime. Itâ€™s a library and itâ€™s not just a syntactic sugar. And E4X, which is a variant of JavaScript that had this exact syntax, it also came with this other weird operational semantics that was totally different than regular JavaScript, had its own runtime library. It was just a mess. But we actually liked the look of it. And I think a lot of people liked the look of it. And thatâ€™s why they like templates. So what we built with React is not about the syntax. Itâ€™s more about functional programming. Itâ€™s about minimizing state mutations. Itâ€™s about the virtual DOM. But for people that really just love their templates and they love how they look, we wanted to give them a way to be able to structure their JavaScript applications without giving up that very balanced structured look of their application. So if you were to write a large app in React with just JavaScript and no syntax extension, youâ€™d notice that it gets difficult to balance those braces with your eyes as your JSON gets really large. Have you ever noticed that? MERRICK:Â  Yeah, for sure. JORDAN:Â  So then the JSX extension, it just simply helps your eyes balance, â€œOkay, well this is the start of that div and this is a span embedded inside of that.â€ Itâ€™s not meaningful to the framework at all. We use it internally so we though, â€œHey, why not just open source this too and see if people like it.â€ PETE:Â  Yeah, and the XML part is just because XML has a very strict notion of opening and closing a tag. Since we basically just translate this markup straight to JavaScript function calls without any sort of crazy transformation, itâ€™s just a little more explicit where your parentheses are going to open and close. MERRICK:Â  Does it allow nesting? Because all the examples seem to show just one instance of a component. So itâ€™s like, â€œHereâ€™s how you would implement a hello message and then this is the declarative way to consume it,â€ and I guess Iâ€™m wondering can you put a hello message and then put something else inside of that and put something else inside of that with some attributes, et cetera? PETE:Â  Oh yeah. This is the big advantage of components over templates. We got a lot of flak for not embracing templates and mixing our markup and our logic in the community initially and we did a pretty poor job of messaging why we think thatâ€™s a good idea. Weâ€™re big proponents at Facebook for separating concerns in a way that makes sense. So we basically think that separating your markup and logic, thatâ€™s not real separation of concerns. Thatâ€™s separation of technologies. If you think about separation of concerns in terms of coupling and cohesion, like the display logic that drives the markup is going to be intimately coupled together. They are a cohesive unit because theyâ€™re both displaying the data. So we basically combine them into a notion called a component. And a component is just a way to render one part of your UI. And one really, really powerful part about components is that they are composable, so you can nest one component inside another and build components out of other components and theyâ€™re all reusable. So we think that thatâ€™s a huge advantage over templates and you basically use components to separate your concerns. We donâ€™t think that the framework or the library can separate your concerns for you. We just want to give you the tools that are powerful enough for you to do it for your application. So to answer your question, yes you can and we encourage it and we think itâ€™s really, really important. MERRICK:Â  Awesome. AJ:Â  So if I can butt in here for a second. I want to go way back to earlier where you were talking about requestAnimationFrame and optimization and I have not yet used requestAnimationFrame. When I first started hearing about it, it was just something that was experimental. It sounds like now, itâ€™s probably been a year since Iâ€™ve heard people really, the big buzz about it. So can you explain a little bit what requestAnimationFrame is and how youâ€™re using it to get performance? PETE:Â  Sure. So weâ€™re not actually using it in React to get performance. We havenâ€™t really found a need for it yet, but itâ€™s an area that we are exploring and experimenting with. What requestAnimation does is it basically says, itâ€™s a function provided by the browser and it takes a function that you pass in. AJ:Â  So is it like window[dot]requestAnimationFrame or window[dot]document[dot]? PETE:Â  Itâ€™s actually, I think in mobile browsers, itâ€™s window.webkit.requestAnimationFrame and moz.requestAnimationFrame but in Chrome I think itâ€™s un-prefixed. But yeah, itâ€™s on window. AJ:Â  Is that for the whole document or is it for a specific subset? PETE:Â  Itâ€™s for the whole window. AJ:Â  Okay. PETE:Â  So the idea with requestAnimationFrame is it will call your function to run right before the browser paints the next page. So the browser paints at 60 FPS so it will call your function within the next 16 milliseconds. And a lot of people are using it to do frame by frame animation and that sort of thing. The reason why I mentioned it earlier was we were talking about batching up operations and doing them all at once to save on performance. So you can imagine, if you do a data fetch and youâ€™re fetching a bunch of data, maybe itâ€™s a Backbone model or something, potentially that might trigger a lot of change events on your Backbone app. Now, if we were using a naÃ¯ve strategy, every single time one of those change events fires, it would mutate the DOM. It would basically do that diff of the trees, compute the DOM mutations and then execute those, flushes DOM mutations to the DOM. And it would do it for each one of those change events. If we were to theoretically implement one based on requestAnimationFrame, we could basically wait until all of those change events have happened and then do the diff and then flush the DOM. This is not a feature thatâ€™s currently in the open source. Itâ€™s something that weâ€™re experimenting with. But I think weâ€™ve all thought that itâ€™s an interesting idea and itâ€™s a way that we could get some more performance and itâ€™s a pluggable part of the API. So someone in the community could go and build it. AJ:Â  So off of that, have you guys had the experience where, in Chrome in particular, have noticed that you get artifacts? Like if you scroll down a page too quickly or if youâ€™ve got one of those CSS selectors where itâ€™s every nth row of a table and artifacts are left over. Do you ever experience that? PETE:Â  What sort of artifacts? Paint artifacts or the DOM is out of sync or something? AJ:Â  Yeah, like one of the nth rows is grey when it should be white, or you scroll and part of a text gets stuck in that place where it was where nothing should be. Because Iâ€™ve encountered this when Iâ€™ve been changing five things at a time, which to me doesnâ€™t seem like a lot, but it just makes me wonder about maybe the requestAnimationFrame would solve that. PETE:Â  For us itâ€™s more about the general idea of batching rather than requestAnimationFrame. AJ:Â  Right, right. PETE:Â  Iâ€™m not sure. How does that work? JORDAN:Â  You know a lot of people are used to having this, as you described it, this artificial divide between a view and then something that controls that view. I think thatâ€™s a great place to start. In fact, a lot of times, Pete and I will start that way when we build an application. But then we realize that this controller logic thatâ€™s controlling this view, thatâ€™s actually something that we want to be able to reuse. So we want to be able to nest that inside of maybe another view. Then we realized that that line that we usually started with between that view and that control logic, it was artificial to really consider that special when we want to package up that whole thing into another component and embed that somewhere else. Does that make sense? And Pete, do you agree? PETE:Â  Yeah. Thatâ€™s going back to composability and components being the language in which you express your separation of concerns. I could chime in about the Instagram-specific use case. JAMISON:Â  Sure. PETE:Â  When we came to Facebook, I joined the Instagram team and Facebook had deployed React on a couple of smaller components, but it hadnâ€™t really been used on a huge app yet.
